ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learned practical museum skills, exhibition curation, and how to think creatively about the role of the museum in society
Writing labels, learning about curatorial practices, specific emphasis on Pre-Modern objects and techniques
I gained a useful insight into museum curatorial skills as well as a more critical view on museums as a whole

There was such a well-thought-out range of art that I began to appreciate all departments and think critically about cross-departmental connections. I was able to think through rational and creative challenges a museum curator faces. I really enjoyed wall label writing and have a new appreciation for it.
Learned so much about museums and curation and all that goes in to creating an exhibit. Really valuable for me to see what a career in museums would look like.

I learned a lot about how museum professionals think about displaying artwork, and particularly how museums are wresting with DEIA questions in their exhibitions (for example, how can a museum exhibition de-center Europe or highlight cross-cultural connections?). I also learned more about art from the early modern period, in a range of different mediums, and about how that art traveled.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I enjoyed the assignments and guest speakers
I think this course was run very well, I can't think of any improvements.

A strength of this course was the number of guest talks, which provided a wide introduction to different areas within the museum. I do think this presented a bit of a challenge, though, because some of the classes felt more like lectures than seminar discussions, and at times I would have appreciated an opportunity to talk more with the class and hear what my peers thought about the various issues raised.

The assignments were also a huge strength of the class - writing object labels was not something I'd ever been asked to do in any of my previous classes, and I appreciated that we went through multiple rounds of edits on them. 

I also think a strength was how seriously Jessie took the class, not just as an academic exercise, but as training for a new generation of curators.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, but mainly if you are interested in early modern art (c. 1500-1800).
Yes- this course was fascinating and highly engaging! Professor Park is a wonderful mentor and teacher of a subject that she is clearly both knowledgeable in and passionate about.
Sure, especially one not that familiar with art history, as it felt geared towards those with less experience at times

I would absolutely recommend this course to anyone interested in museum studies, art history, and/or museums in general. It is pretty laid-back but you get so much out of it by engaging. This is an extraordinary and unique course that any student at Yale should take with our Gallery being so accessible.
Yes I absolutely would! Especially anyone interested in a career in museums or in the art world, this course was incredible and so informative and interesting.

Yes, I would, especially if you are interested in working in museums or thinking about the role of art museums. The class strikes a nice balance between being art historically focused (on the early modern period) and museum focused. The work is nicely spaced out and there are no major paper assignments, just a series of shorter papers, object labels, and a final project. The final project (designing a museum exhibition proposal) gave us a lot of creative freedom and was a fun, engaging project.

extras.title: HSAR 403 01 - Museum as Agent of Change
